Introduction

Nature has been forming groups since the beginning of time, from the Big Bang onwards (History Tracers, 2024), and as natural beings, we instinctively follow this pattern. Human groups don't always form with the intention of achieving something specific; rather, some groups are formed in pursuit of a common goal, such as equality (History Tracers, 2024). One notable example of such groups is attributed to Christian Jurgensen Thomsen, who categorized human prehistory into the Stone Age, Bronze Age (2300-700 BCE), and Iron Age (700-1 BCE) through his "Three-Age System" (Heizer, R. F., 1962, pp. 259 ; Barzun, J. et al., 2023, The Metal Ages). While Thomsen's conclusions are relevant in a European context, the question arises: can they be applied to Abya Yala/America?

As we delve into historical periods, Europe offers us the concept of the Middle Ages (500 to 1400-1500 D.C.), a period heavily influenced by the Christian worldview (Barzun, J. et al., 2023, The Metal Ages). Previously termed the Dark Ages, this period is now commonly referred to as the Migration Period (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, 2018). However, can we use a period defined by a worldview absent in Abya Yala/América prior to the arrival of European settlers to understand the Indigenous peoples of the region?

Challenges with Three-Age System

In examining Robert F. Heizer's work it is necessary to address the following points:
  • He categorizes the human prehistory into distinct periods Stone Age, Bronze Age (2300 - 700 A.C), and Iron Age (700 - 1 A.C) (Heizer, R. F., 1962, pp. 259).
  • His work contains assertions suggesting European cultural superiority over Indigenous cultures (Heizer, R. F., 1962, pp. 260 - 261), which lacks empirical basis (History Tracers, 2024).
  • Heizer also refutes the notion of a 6000-year-old Earth, demonstrating its inaccuracy (Heizer, R. F., 1962, pp. 261 - 262).

Regarding the misconception of Indigenous history, labeling the inhabitants of Abya Yala/América as "selvage" demonstrates a profound misunderstanding. For instance, the people of Caral, Peru (Ruta Caral, 2024 ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, 2024), potentially developed a written language (Mann, Charles C., 2005, pp. 1008 ; History Tracers, 2024) and constructed sophisticated buildings and social structures, positioning their city as one of the earliest urban centers globally (Mann, Charles C., 2005, pp. 1008).
Figure 1: Photo of piramid H1 in the arqueological site of Caral (Ruta Caral, 2024 ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, 2024). Photo taken on June 13, 2017 during a visit to the site.
Moving forward in time, Teotihuacan in North America flourished with a population of 100,000 inhabitants, ranking as the sixth-largest city worldwide (INAH, 2024).
Figure 2: General photo of Teotihuacan city. Photo taken on October 20, 2016 during a visit to the site.

Another issue pertinent to Indigenous history is the oversimplification of historical periods to only Bronze and Iron Ages. Metallurgical evidence suggests that Indigenous peoples in Abya Yala/América, in metalworking, utilizing Copper (CU), Silver (Ag) and Gold (Au) for over three millennia in the southern regions (Guédron, S., et al., 2021). Moreover, maritime trade facilitated the dissemination of these technologies throughout the Abya Yala/Américan continent (Hosler, D., 1988).

Challenges with historical time

The term "Middle Age" delineates a specific period in European history (Barzun, J. et al., 2023, The Middle Ages). However, its applicability to Abya Yala/Americaraises questions about the suitability of using Eurocentric frameworks. Shouldn't each continent and its inhabitants have their own distinct periods? The emergence of the Renaissance in Europe, characterized by a resurgence of classical Greece and Roma and a "march of modernity and progress" (Barzun, J. et al., 2023, The Renaissance), illustrates the unique trajectory of European history. Contrary to events in Abya Yala/América, such as those in Mesoamerica (Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México) and the Andes (National Museum of the American Indian), it becomes evident that a broader understanding of Indigenous history requires distinct periods.

Reflection 1: Regarding the word history
Human history is commonly divided into two epochs: history and prehistory, typically marked by the advent of writing systems. Given the diversity of human experiences, should we further segment historical periods based on specific populations?

Archaeological Periods on the Abya Yala/Américan

The vast expanse of the Abya Yala/Américan continent continent necessitates a nuanced approach to archaeological periods, as advocated by John Howland Rowe (Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 265 - 266). Subsequent research by Rowe further explores the relationship between periods and stages, enriching the discourse (Rowe, J. H., 1962).

The initial period, known as the Lithic period, is marked by uncertainty. While it is generally accepted that human presence on the continent dates back approximately 13,500 years, recent studies suggest the possibility of an even earlier arrival, around 30,000 years ago (Roca-Rada, Xavier, et al., 2020, pp. 2 ; Becerra-Valdivia, L., Higham, T., 2020 ; Pirula, 2017). These discrepancies underscore the evolving nature of knowledge (Ferro Virginia, Maria. Virgina 2013)), facilitated by the Scientific Method (History Tracers (2024): Scientific Method). In light of this, we will adopt the most commonly utilized timeframe found in various scholarly works:

In various regions, identical names are employed to denote different historical periods. Therefore, it is advisable to consistently pair the name with its corresponding region to prevent confusion.

Conclusion

The categorization of human Ages is inherently tied to the understanding of specific regions. Attempting to apply these definitions to disparate locations can lead to inaccuracies in depicting local events. Furthermore, the definition of Ages remains subject to revision as new research emerges and knowledge progresses.
